answer_html: \(W=25\) So the work done in stretching the spring is 25J.
answer_latex: $W=25$ So the work done in stretching the spring is 25J.
hints_html:
Remember that force is \(kx\) for a spring. But what is \(k\) here?

Work is force multiplied by distance, for constant force. In this case, force is not constant - what would the formula for work be?
hints_latex: Remember that force is $kx$ for a spring. But what is $k$ here?

Work is force multiplied by distance, for constant force. In this case,
force is not constant - what would the formula for work be?
hints_raw:
Remember that force is <math> kx </math> for a spring. But what is <math> k </math> here?
Work is force multiplied by distance, for constant force. In this case, force is not constant - what would the formula for work be?
question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
Recall for springs,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = kx\end{aligned}\]

We are given that force is 10 N when \(x\) is 5 cm = 0.05 m, so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 10 = k(0.05)\end{aligned}\]

giving \(\displaystyle k = 200\). Then, the work done in stretching the spring from its natural length to 50 cm = 0.5 m beyond its natural length is given by

\[\begin{aligned} W &= \int_0^{0.5} 200x \ dx \\ &= 200 \frac{x^2}2 \big|_0^{0.5} \\ &= 25\end{aligned}\]

So the work done in stretching the spring is 25J.
sols_raw:
Recall for springs,

:<math> 
 \displaystyle 
f(x) = kx
</math>

We are given that force is 10 N when <math> x </math> is 5 cm = 0.05 m, so

:<math> 
 \displaystyle 
10 = k(0.05)
</math>

giving <math> \displaystyle  k = 200</math>. Then, the work done in stretching the spring from its natural length to 50 cm  = 0.5 m beyond its natural length is given by

:<math> 
\begin{align}
W & = \int_0^{0.5} 200x \ dx \\
& = 200 \frac{x^2}2 \big|_0^{0.5} \\
& = 25
\end{align}
</math>

So the work done in stretching the spring is 25J.
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Question 1-3 are short-answer questions. Put your answer in the box provided. Simplify your answer as much as possible. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct answer placed in the box. Show your work, for part marks.

A force of 10 N (newtons) is required to hold a spring stretched 5 cm beyond its natural length. How much work, in joules (J), is done in stretching the spring from its natural length to 50 cm beyond its natural length?
